tztwh wrote:
> 
> I've written a processor to write one URI resource into one file,
> thus mirroring (more or less) the files on a server.  It handles
> long URIs, characters that aren't allowed in file names, and
> both case-sensitive and case-insensitive file systems.
> 
> It's had limited testing with Heritrix 1.0.4 on a Mac OS X 10.2.8
> system running java 1.4.1_01.
> 
> It does not rewrite HTML, unlike, for example, wget.
> 
> Let me know it you'd like it.

Yes, sounds very interesting. Igor has built a similar tool internally
for "unrolling" ARC files to disk.

Can you explain the rules you use to coerce URIs into
acceptable filenames?

Is the process completely deterministic -- without consulting
what's already in the target directory?

The drawback of not patching the HTML is that browsing from
the local files is unlikely to give satisfactory results --
an absolute and many relative URIs will not resolve to captured
versions properly.

I think it might be possible to make a Javascript-based local-files
Wayback Machine -- that loads the local file into a frame (or IFRAME),
patches the inline resource URIs dynamically (like the public Wayback
Machine), and captures any attempts to browse outside the frame,
redirecting it back to the captured local files. If the
Javascript and the captured files are both coming from the same local
disks, it should be able to do all the necessary steps, without
ever changing the files themselves.

- Gordon @ IA
